moves.1. d4: This is another game from the Knights of Honor Upper Level Tourney.  This game became wildly tactical early on.
moves.1... g6: Black goes with his favorite defense-The Modern/Robatsch.
moves.2. e4 Bg7 3. f4: With 3. f4, White initiates the aptly named Three Pawns Attack.
moves.3... d6 4. Nf3 c5: Here, Black seeks to begin undermining White's center.
moves.5. dxc5: 5. dxc5.  This move surprised me a bit.  I fully expected 5. d5
moves.5... Qa5+: Black didn't want to take c5 with d6 as it likely would have led to an exchange of Queens and pull the d-pawn out of the center.
moves.6. Nc3: Here again, White surprised me as I expected Bd2
moves.7. Nd5 Nf6: 7...Nf6  Fritz gave this move a ? and recommended 7.	... Qa5+  8.	Bd2  Qd8  That never crossed my mind but in hindsight, that would have certainly led to a calmer game.  Additionally, I think it was only an oversight by White that I didn't lose my Queen for his LSB in the next couple of moves.
moves.8. b4 Qc6: This was a relatively simple move as every other move lost the Queen.
moves.9. Ne5: 9. Ne5  I'm hesitant to offer a ? on a move when my opponent is 250 rating points better.  However, I believe that 9. Bb5  Qxb5  10.	Nc7+	wins Black's Queen.  I didn't see this possibility until after 9. Ne5 as I was certain that a 2000+ player simply didn't see that dxNe5 was possible.  I was literally ready to move 9. dxe5 three times but each time did not click on 'Submit' as I was certain that I was missing something.  Once I saw I could lose the Queen, I came up with a different move.
moves.11. Nc7+: This was expected but there was little I could do about it.
moves.11... Kd7 12. Nxa8 Nxe4: 12. Nxe4  My thought here was that I was attacking Ra1 and if e1xd1, then Nf2 forks the K and R.  However, my friend fritz gave this move two ?? and suggested 12...Nxc6 13. b5 Nb4
moves.13. Ne5+ dxe5: and material is getting closer to equal.
moves.14. Bd3 exf4: And again Black's DSB eyes Ra1.
moves.15. Bxe4 Bxa1 16. Kxd1 Nc6: Now Na8 is in danger as is b4.
moves.17. b5 Nd4 18. b6 f5: 18...f5.  fritz gives this a ? and recommended e5.  I think if I had seen this, I would have been happier.  With 18...f5, I was thinking that if Bxb7, my R can go to b8 and win a piece.
moves.19. Bxb7 Rb8: 19. Rb8??  I miss the tactic completely and with this move, the game is essentially over.  Much better would have been 19...axb6
moves.21... Rxb6 22. a8=Q Rd6: Better may have been Nc6 but Black is busted at this point.
moves.23. Bxf4 Rc6 24. Qb7+ Ke8 25. Bg5 Kd8 26: For a brief time, I felt like I was in this game.  I take solace in the words of Capablanca--"One can profit more from a single loss than a hundred wins."  My thanks to jonstherealdeal for the game.  Even though I lost--and still feel pain over 19...Rb8, this was an enjoyable (and interesting) game.  As always, comments/critiques are most welcome
